name: Order Capital Round 1 (Codeforces Round 1038, Div. 1 + Div. 2)

problems.title: Greedy Grid
problems.statementHtml:
A path in a grid is called greedy if it starts at the top-left cell and moves only to the right or downward, always moving to its neighbor with the greater value (or either if the values are equal).

The value of a path is the sum of the values of the cells it visits, including the start and end.

Does there exist an n×mn×m grid of nonnegative integers such that no greedy path achieves the maximum value among all down/right paths?
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤50001≤t≤5000). The description of the test cases follows.

The only line of each test case contains two integers nn, mm (1≤n,m≤1001≤n,m≤100) — the number of rows and columns in the grid, respectively.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, on a separate line output "YES" if the required grid exists, and "NO" otherwise.

You can output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "yEs", "yes", "Yes", and "YES" will be recognized as positive responses.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, an example of a grid in which no greedy path achieves the maximum value out of all down/right paths is:

⎡⎣⎢325514123⎤⎦⎥[351212543]
Let ai,jai,j denote the value of the cell in the ii-th row and jj-th column. The maximum value of a down/right path is a1,1+a2,1+a3,1+a3,2+a3,3=17a1,1+a2,1+a3,1+a3,2+a3,3=17. This path isn't greedy because a1,2a1,2 is greater than a2,1a2,1; thus, a greedy path must move right in the first step. The maximum value of a greedy path is a1,1+a1,2+a2,2+a3,2+a3,3=16a1,1+a1,2+a2,2+a3,2+a3,3=16.

In the second test case, it can be proven that no grid satisfies the conditions.

problems.title: Pile Shuffling
problems.statementHtml:
You are given nn binary piles, the ii-th of which consists of aiai zeros on the top and bibi ones on the bottom.

In one operation, you can take the top element of any pile and move it to any position in any pile, including the pile it was taken from.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105) — the number of piles.

Then nn lines follow, the ii-th containing four integers aiai, bibi, cici, didi (0≤ai,bi,ci,di≤1090≤ai,bi,ci,di≤109) — the original and target state of the ii-th pile.

It is guaranteed that there exists a sequence of operations that transforms the piles into the target state.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output one integer — the minimum number of operations required to achieve the target state.
problems.noteHtml:
The solution of the first test case is shown in the statement.

In the second test case, an optimal solution is to do the following:

In the third test case, all piles are already in their target state.

problems.title: Manhattan Pairs
problems.statementHtml:
You are given nn points (xi,yi)(xi,yi) on a 2D plane, where nn is even. Select n2n2 disjoint pairs (ai,bi)(ai,bi) to maximize the sum of Manhattan distances between points in pairs. In other words, maximize

∑i=1n/2|xai−xbi|+|yai−ybi|.∑i=1n/2|xai−xbi|+|yai−ybi|.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single even integer nn (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105) — the number of points.

The ii-th of the next nn lines contains two integers xixi and yiyi (−106≤xi,yi≤106−106≤xi,yi≤106) — the coordinates of the ii-th point.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output n2n2 lines, the ii-th line containing two integers aiai and bibi — the indices of points in the ii-th pair.

If there are multiple solutions, print any of them.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, an optimal solution is to select the pairs (1,4)(1,4) and (2,3)(2,3), which achieves a distance sum of 5+3=85+3=8.

In the second test case, an optimal solution is to select the pairs (1,8)(1,8), (9,10)(9,10), (5,7)(5,7), (2,3)(2,3), (4,6)(4,6), which achieves a distance sum of 4+7+10+5+7=334+7+10+5+7=33.

problems.title: Traffic Lights
problems.statementHtml:
You are given a simple undirected connected graph of nn vertices and mm edges.

There is a token in vertex 11. We consider the initial time to be at 00 seconds. After tt seconds, if the token is in vertex uu, you must do exactly one of the following:

The order of edges of a vertex is the order that they appear in the input.

Calculate the minimum time required to move the token from vertex 11 to vertex nn, and the minimum time spent waiting that can be achieved while minimizing the total time.

∗∗xmodyxmody denotes the remainder from dividing xx by yy.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤10001≤t≤1000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn, mm (2≤n≤50002≤n≤5000, n−1≤m≤n(n−1)2n−1≤m≤n(n−1)2) — the number of vertices and edges in the graph, respectively.

Then mm lines follow, the ii-th line containing two integers uiui and vivi (1≤ui,vi≤n1≤ui,vi≤n) — the vertices of the ii-th edge.

It is guaranteed that the graph is connected and simple.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 50005000, and the sum of mm over all test cases does not exceed 5⋅1055⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single line containing two integers — the minimum total time and the minimum waiting time that minimizes the total time, respectively.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, an optimal strategy is to do the following:

  • at time 00, wait one second,
  • at time 11, move the token from vertex 11 to vertex 55,
  • at time 22, wait one second,
  • at time 33, move the token from vertex 55 to vertex 66.

In the second test case, an optimal strategy is to do the following:

  • at time 00, move the token from vertex 11 to vertex 22,
  • at time 11, move the token from vertex 22 to vertex 11,
  • at time 22, move the token from vertex 11 to vertex 44.

problems.title: Greedy Grid Counting
problems.statementHtml:
A path in a grid is called greedy if it starts at the top-left cell and moves only to the right or downward, always moving to its neighbor with the greater value (or either if the values are equal).

The value of a path is the sum of the values of the cells it visits, including the start and end.

Given a partially filled 2×n2×n grid of integers between 11 and kk, count the number of ways to fill the empty cells such that in every subgrid∗∗, there exists a greedy path that achieves the maximum value out of all down/right paths. Since the answer may be large, calculate it modulo 998244353998244353.

∗∗ A subgrid of a 2×n2×n grid ai,jai,j is a grid formed from all cells ax,yax,y such that lx≤x≤rxlx≤x≤rx, ly≤y≤ryly≤y≤ry for some 1≤lx≤rx≤21≤lx≤rx≤2, 1≤ly≤ry≤n1≤ly≤ry≤n.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤5001≤t≤500). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and kk (1≤n,k≤5001≤n,k≤500) — the number of columns and the range of integers in the grid, respectively.

Then two lines follow, the ii-th line containing nn integers ai,1,ai,2,…,ai,nai,1,ai,2,…,ai,n (−1≤ai,j≤k−1≤ai,j≤k, ai,j≠0ai,j≠0) — the values of cells in the ii-th row of the grid, where −1−1 represents an empty cell.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 500500.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer — the number of ways to fill the grid that satisfy the above conditions, modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the grids that satisfy the conditions are:

[22111123],[22121123],[22131123],[22122123],[22132123],[22133123].[21122113],[21122213],[21122313],[21222213],[21222313],[21322313].

In the second test case, all ways to fill the grid satisfy the conditions.

problems.title: Colorful Polygon
problems.statementHtml:
You are given an array a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an, where n≤8n≤8 and a1+a2+⋯+an≤100a1+a2+⋯+an≤100.

Construct a simple polygon∗∗ with at most 333333 vertices that has exactly

(a1+a2+⋯+an)!a1!a2!⋯an!(a1+a2+⋯+an)!a1!a2!⋯an!
different triangulations††. It can be proven that such a polygon always exists.

∗∗A simple polygon is a polygon that does not intersect itself and has no holes. In other words, no two non-consecutive edges can have common points, and consecutive edges must have exactly one common point — the vertex between them. Consecutive edges may be collinear.

††A triangulation of a polygon with mm vertices is a set of m−3m−3 diagonals that intersect only at vertices. A diagonal is a segment between two vertices which lies inside the polygon and has exactly two common points with the polygon sides — the vertices it connects.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
The first line of each test contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤82≤n≤8) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤1001≤ai≤100) — the elements of the array.

It is guaranteed that a1+a2+⋯+ana1+a2+⋯+an does not exceed 100100.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
In the first line, output a single integer mm (3≤m≤3333≤m≤333) — the number of vertices in the polygon.

In the ii-th of the following mm lines, output two integers xixi, yiyi (−106≤xi,yi≤106−106≤xi,yi≤106) — the coordinates of the ii-th vertex of the polygon.

The polygon must be simple. The vertices may be given in either clockwise or counterclockwise order.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test, the required polygon has to have 4!1!1!2!=124!1!1!2!=12 triangulations. The following are all the triangulations of the example polygon.

In the second test, the required polygon has to have 5!4!1!=55!4!1!=5 triangulations.

problems.title: Tree Parking
problems.statementHtml:
Consider the following problem statement:

You are given a tree with nn vertices rooted at 11. For each 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n, a car will enter the root at time lili. It will then instantaneously travel from the root to vertex ii through the unique simple path and park there. It will leave through the same path in the other direction at time riri.

During the time when a car is parked in a vertex, it blocks other cars from traveling through that vertex. The tree is called valid if and only if all cars are able to enter and leave the tree at their desired times.

Count the number of pairs of sequences ll, rr such that li<rili<ri, their concatenation is a permutation of 1…2n1…2n, and the tree is valid.

Calculate the sum of the answers to the problem over all labeled trees∗∗ with nn vertices and kk leaves. The root is not considered a leaf. Since the answer may be large, calculate it modulo 998244353998244353.

∗∗Two labeled trees are considered different if and only if their edge sets are different.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The only line of each test case contains two integers nn, kk (1≤k<n≤2⋅1051≤k<n≤2⋅105) — the number of vertices and leaves of the tree, respectively.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output one integer — the answer modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first case, there is only one tree that satisfies the constraints. The correct pairs of sequences are:

(l,r)=([1,3],[2,4]),([3,1],[4,2]),([2,1],[3,4]).(l,r)=([1,3],[2,4]),([3,1],[4,2]),([2,1],[3,4]).

tutorial.contentHtml:
2122A - Greedy Grid

Solution

2122A - Greedy Grid

If n=1n=1 or m=1m=1, there's only one down/right path, so it is trivially greedy and maximal.

If n=m=2n=m=2, any path must choose between two neighbors after the first step. Clearly, moving greedily always leads to a maximal path.

In all other cases, such a grid does exist. Assuming n≤mn≤m, start with an n×mn×m grid filled with ones, and modify the top-left 2×32×3 subgrid as follows:

[132131].[123311].
It's easy to verify that in this grid, no greedy path achieves the maximum possible value.
